LEAD: A new line of dolls that kneel and clasp their hands in a gesture of prayer has drawn mixed reactions from religious groups.
A new line of dolls that kneel and clasp their hands in a gesture of prayer has drawn mixed reactions from religious groups.

Kenner Parker Toys Inc. of Beverly, Mass., says it is marketing the 15-inch dolls under the name ''Special Blessings'' to capitalize on a growing national interest in traditional values. The dolls will be available in stores next month for about $20.
''Our studies have shown that Americans are turning increasingly to religion and traditional values,'' David M. Mauer, president of the company's Kenner Products Division, said in a recent interview.
Store orders were brisk for the dolls, said Dick Ostrander, the company's sales manager for New England. The dolls clasp their palms with the help of Velcro.
Officials of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops and the National Council of Churches declined to comment on the praying dolls, but others expressed concern.

Dr. Ronald Russo, executive secretary of the Religious Education Association of the United States and Canada, which has a membership of 3,500 religious educators, said: ''I don't think prayer is something to be commercialized. Nor do I want to see these things advertised as a simplistic remedy to spiritual problems that people may have.''
